conclusion: Objects A and B move through the air and are placed down at the location of objects C, D, E, and F, coming into contact with the blocks due to gravity.
The two pieces of fabric form short ramps that slope down toward the blocks on the table.
As soon as the airborne objects A (left) and B (right) touch those ramps, gravity makes them slide straight ahead.
Object A runs into the green cube C first and immediately shoves it into the red cuboid D; both small blocks are pushed out of position and tip over.
Object B hits the blue cube E, drives it into the tall gray block F, and the narrow gray block loses balance and falls.

A will slide into C and D, toppling them, and B will slide into E and F, toppling them as well; in the end all four blocks (C, D, E, F) are knocked over or pushed away, with A and B coming to rest next to the displaced blocks.
